column3:
This effectively reduces duplicate calls to CTransaction::GetHash() to zero.

There are a few duplicates but I believe those to be the coinbase transactions which are actually identical.

I have not reviewed for correctness.

Actually those appear to be something to do with the genesis block.

Either way it's a trivial number of duplicate calls.
Added a commit that removes all function arguments that were hashes of a CTransaction that is already passed, resulting in simpler code in many places.\n
Spiffy! I like it! Untested ACK\n
@pstratem What were your benchmark results? I remember something like 17% faster reindex to block 180k or so?\n
@sipa benchmarks show a ~15% faster reindex to block 150k\n
I've been testing this on my nodes for ~2 weeks with no problems.\n
@gavinandresen Can you make some space for pulltester?\n

Automatic sanity-testing: PASSED, see http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-tester/p4309_d38da59bf68fbb37535e2579bfb7355a16baed0e/ for binaries and test log.\nThis test script verifies pulls every time they are updated. It, however, dies sometimes and fails to test properly.  If you are waiting on a test, please check timestamps to verify that the test.log is moving at http://jenkins.bluematt.me/pull-te

This change seems unnecessary?  As a grep of all CMutableTransaction uses helpfully highlights, there is never a case where a TX is accessed in parallel or stored in a parallel-access container while also being mutated.

As such, you may apply the common "I'm done mutating this data structure, update cached data" pattern without needing a new class.

ETA: I'm posting this on a closed issue bec
